WHAT DAHL-WOLFE'S EYE CREATED IN A LENS 

  (ART ADV: NYT Photos 13,14 are being sent to NYT photo clients.
Nonsubscribers can purchase one-time rights by calling 888-603-1036
or 888-346-9867.) 
 c.2000 N.Y. Times News Service    

   NEW YORK _ When Carmen Dell'Orefice was 15 and modeling to help
her mother pay the rent on a Third Avenue walk-up, she made a visit
to the 57th Street studio of Louise Dahl-Wolfe. At the time, 1946,
Dahl-Wolfe, 51, was in her 10th year as the reigning photographer
at Harper's Bazaar and her umpteenth as a woman who looked like a
home economics teacher at a girls' reform school.

   ``She seemed ancient,'' Dell'Orefice recalled a few weeks ago.
``The first thing she said to me was, `Your mother shouldn't let
you wear makeup.''' When Dell'Orefice answered that she wasn't
wearing any, the photographer dragged her to a window and pinched
her eyelashes for proof. Finally, Dell'Orefice was sent home on the
grounds that she was too young to stand in front of a tripod for
money, or at least too young for Bazaar's older readers. Not long
after, she appeared on the cover of Vogue.

   Louise Dahl-Wolfe would see dozens of models rise and fall
before she died 43 years later, in 1989, at 94. On June 12, the
Museum of the Fashion Institute of Technology will present the
first full-scale retrospective of her work, little of which points
to the kind of benighted sensibility her behavior, and a hair bun
slathered with beeswax, might have led one to expect.

   Curated by Irving Solero and Nan Richardson, the exhibition will
run through Aug. 12 and move to the Center for Creative Photography
in Tucson in September. A companion book by Richardson, ``Louise
Dahl-Wolfe: A Retrospective,'' is due from Harry N. Abrams this
summer. Some of Dahl-Wolfe's black-and-white images are on view at
the Staley-Wise gallery.

   During her time at Bazaar, a 22-year tenure that ended when she
quit in 1958, after the magazine's editor, Carmel Snow, and the
legendary art director Alexey Brodovitch both resigned, Dahl-Wolfe
chronicled the birth of a looser, less pinched spirit in American
fashion. With Diana Vreeland as her fashion editor, Dahl-Wolfe
traveled around the world, shooting that new concept, sportswear,
out of doors where it comfortably breathed. Before the triumvirate
of Snow, Vreeland and Dahl-Wolfe, American style, as Richard Avedon
has put it, did not exist.

   ``Louise has a pivotal role moving fashion photography out of
formal studio work into a portrayal of the active, modern American
woman,'' Amy Rule, an archivist at the Center for Creative
Photography, said.

   Other photographers, like Martin Munkacsi and Toni Frissell,
were already capturing the new mood, but Dahl-Wolfe distinguished
herself with images that implied a languorous sexuality. She often
photographed models on the beach, in repose, their eyes closed or
averted, their bodies positioned _ trapped _ rigidly in the frame.
Dahl-Wolfe seemed to realize that new sportswear by Claire
McCardell and Bonnie Cashin offered women the semblance of an
unconstricted life, not the real freedom that only a challenge to
accepted social arrangements could bring.

   The daughter of a Norwegian marine engineer, Louise Dahl was
born in San Francisco in 1895 and showed no tendencies during her
young womanhood to live within the narrow corridor of risk laid out
for her sex. After studying art in San Francisco, she moved to New
York to take classes in architecture and design. In 1927, she
embarked on a tour of Europe with her friend Consuela Kanaga, a
news photographer. A year went by, and when the women were bored
with the Continent they headed for North Africa.

   It was on a train platform in Tunisia in 1928 that Dahl, 32,
spotted her future husband, a sculptor from Tennessee named Meyer
Wolfe. ``She saw him,'' Irving Solero, who befriended Dahl-Wolfe in
1978, recalled, ``and said, `That's for me.''' The two married that
same year.

   Without fail, those who knew Dahl-Wolfe remark on the intense
bond she and her husband shared. ``They lived together nonstop, 24
hours a day,'' said Solero, who spent time with the couple in their
Frenchtown, N.J., home, known as the Creamery. ``They fought all
the time, but a fight would erupt for five seconds and then it was
over.'' Wolfe would travel with his wife, typically picking her up
for lunch during out-of-town shoots.

   ``When he died at 88 she was self-abandoned,'' Mary Jane
Russell, a friend and favorite model of Dahl-Wolfe's, said
recently. ``Her mourning was coupled with anger: `How could he have
left me? Why couldn't I be first?'''

   While she was close to Russell, her relationships with others in
the Harper's Bazaar orbit were more complex. Well into the '70s and
'80s, Dahl-Wolfe would talk about her former colleague Avedon ``as
though he were a kid,'' Solero said, adding, ``She'd say, `He has a
long way to go.'''

   Lillian Bassman, whose impressionistic photographs began
appearing in Bazaar around 1950, said that Dahl-Wolfe repeatedly
tried to have her fired. In the mid-'40s, when Bassman was still
working in the magazine's art department as an apprentice, Carmel
Snow sent her to Paris to try to find photographers who had worked
for Bazaar before the war. Dahl-Wolfe was so irritated at the
prospect of competition, Bassman said, that she complained to Snow
that the art-director-in-training had been maligning her. Snow
swiftly dispatched Bassman to the country and out of the way. ``It
was a testimony to Louise's stature at the magazine,'' Bassman
said. After that, their relationship was ``a mess,'' she added.

   With underlings in the fashion department, Dahl-Wolfe often
played the taskmaster. Some 50 years ago, the fashion editor Polly
Mellen traveled to Jamaica with Dahl-Wolfe for a shoot and recalled
waking up every morning at 4:30 to braid the hair that would
eventually be cranked into the photographer's signature bun. ``In
my growing years, she was one of the few people who really formed
me,'' Mellen said. ``She taught me extreme discipline.'' And
demonstrated a certain largesse as well. When Mellen left Bazaar to
marry in 1952, Dahl-Wolfe gave her a going-away party and took her
wedding pictures. ``If she was on your side, you were most
fortunate,'' Mellen said.

   After Dahl-Wolfe left Bazaar, she worked briefly for Vogue
before relinquishing photography in 1960, saying that advertisers
had gained too much influence over magazines. But however
frustrated she had become with what she saw as the
commercialization of magazines, she was never the sort who demanded
that some notion of artistic vision take precedence over the
business of showing off clothes. One hallmark of her thousands of
published images, 86 Bazaar covers among them, is that the gowns
and bathing suits and ski clothes are always visible front and
center. ``She worked for the magazine because she showed the
frocks,'' said Martin Harrison, a curator and historian of
photography. ``The models were good-looking, and it was a great
time for American fashion.''

   Even Harrison, a detractor, admits that Dahl-Wolfe had a talent
for color. In her effort to show garments to their best advantage,
she would typically go to the printing press where Bazaar was
churned out and nudge engravers to change a blue backdrop to, say,
a yellow one if it made a dress look better. ``It was almost as if
she were a set designer,'' said Christopher Greene, who produced
prints from Dahl-Wolfe's negatives late in her life.

   While Dahl-Wolfe might flinch at the sort of images that today
fill the pages of avant-garde fashion magazines like Dazed and
Confused, the striking, saturated colors that are their trademark
hark back, in some sense, to her. Before the rise of digital
technology, it was impossible to reproduce prints from Dahl-Wolfe's
Kodachromes that resembled what appeared on the printed page.

   That is one reason, said Richardson, the Fashion Institute
curator, that a coffee-table book of her work has never been
published before.

   Another is that Dahl-Wolfe always thought the notion rather
flashy and pretentious.
